info.game_comments:
Kevin Marshall game 3.

(Sarah: Don't pull your ripcord yet!  We've got plenty of adrenaline-pumping clues with the Golden Knights next on Jeopardy!)

(1, 1).clue: The highest low temperature of any U.S. state is the 12 degrees F. recorded in this state on May 17, 1979

(3, 1).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from Fort Bragg, NC, holding a parachute.)  Packing of all reserve chutes in the United States, even those used by the Army's Golden Knights, is overseen by this federal organization

(4, 1).clue: Each member of the House of Representatives represents one of these territorial divisions of a state

(5, 1).clue: She was still a teenager when Howard Hughes discovered her in 1940

(6, 1).clue: I go to the spa in the nude

(1, 2).clue: On a weather map, 3 horizontal & parallel lines indicate this weather condition

(2, 2).clue: "Outside of a dog, a book is man's best friend. Inside of a dog, it's too dark to read"

(3, 2).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew holds open a parachute at Fort Bragg, NC.)  Though they may still say "hit the silk", the Golden Knights use a ripstop version of this synthetic fabric, created by Dupont in the '30s

(4, 2).clue: She was the first British monarch to address the U.S. Congress

(5, 2).clue: In 1976, this high-flying woman was simply gym-dandy

(1, 3).clue: The Fujita scale that ranks the intensity of these goes from F-0 on up; an F-5 has wind speeds exceeding 261 mph

(2, 3).clue: "Louis, I think this is the beginning of a beautiful friendship"

(3, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew demonstrates with a parachute at Fort Bragg, NC.) Also found on cars,  when these steering lines are used dually, they slow the parachute; singly, they allow turning

(4, 3).clue: We swear, the very first law passed by Congress concerned how these pledges were to be made

(5, 3).clue: He's the famous Russian seen here in 1961

(1, 4).clue: Sadly, in 2005 many learned this alliterative 2-word term for a rise in sea level accompanying fierce winds

(2, 4).clue: "I'm lookin' at a tin star with a drunk pinned on it"

(3, 4).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew reports from a runway at Fort Bragg, NC.) The Army employs two jumping methods: a static line in which the jumper is tethered to the plane, & this style, reminiscent of a Tom Petty tune

(4, 4).clue: Frustrated with his own political party, in 2001 this senator from Vermont switched to indepedent

(5, 4).clue: Before her time as a First Lady, this woman was a radio & film actress

(1, 5).clue: This type of weather radar calculates the speed & direction of a weather system

(3, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew prepares to jump from an aircraft at Fort Bragg, NC.)  Beginning parachuters usually jump with a partner, referred to as this term from the Latin for "at length"

(4, 5).clue: Former senators are allowed back on the Senate floor, but they're restricted from doing this the first year out of office

(5, 5).clue: He's the World War I military leader & member of royalty seen here

(1, 1).clue: George Custer was wounded only once during the war but had 11 of these killed under him

(2, 1).clue: The 2005-2006 TV season marks this famous Ed's 25th year on "60 Minutes"

(3, 1).clue: This city is the capital of the high-altitude autonomous region that until 1965 was its own country

(4, 1).clue: "Green Coca-Cola Bottles" (1962) & other pieces of pop art are part of this science

(5, 1).clue: It was during this war that Lt. Andrew Rowan delivered his famous "Message to Garcia" from Pres. McKinley

(6, 1).clue: Small dry twigs used to start a fire

(1, 2).clue: A young conscript from North Carolina was called this, slang for the peanuts grown there

(2, 2).clue: He was nominated for an Oscar for playing an abstract expressionist in a 2000 film that he directed himself

(3, 2).clue: Chengdu is the hot & spicy capital of this province that lends its name to a hot & spicy Chinese food variety

(4, 2).clue: If you avidly follow Latin American soccer, you're gaining knowledge in this area

(5, 2).clue: In August 1858 the first transatlantic cable message was sent from this monarch to Pres. Buchanan

(6, 2).clue: Congo capital founded by Henry Stanley

(1, 3).clue: During the war, this Ozark state had 2 competing governments

(2, 3).clue: This conservation-conscious co-star of St. Elsewhere was once L.A.'s environmental affairs commissioner

(3, 3).clue: This capital of the island province of Hainan sounds like a short Japanese poem of 17 syllables

(4, 3).clue: Get a Ph.D. studying products released in a spray through a nozzle & you're an expert in this

(5, 3).clue: After defeating a British fleet on Lake Erie, he sent out the message "We have met the enemy, and they are ours"

(6, 3).clue: A film of a transmitted television program

(1, 4).clue: This Confederate submarine was recovered in 2000; its crew was buried in Charleston in 2004

(2, 4).clue: He showed off his singing pipes when he played Drew Barrymore's fiance in the film "Everyone Says I Love You"

(4, 4).clue: Need a minty flavoring for candies or cigarettes?  Call someone who knows about this

(5, 4).clue: On May 24, 1844 he sent the famous message, "What hath God wrought"

(6, 4).clue: From the Greek for "movement", this real -ology studies mechanics with respect to human anatomy

(1, 5).clue: This term that means an ambusher & also inlcudes "B-U-S-H" gets that meaning from Civil War guerrillas

(2, 5).clue: In 1995 he wrote, directed & starred in his first film, "The Brothers McMullen"

(3, 5).clue: This capital of Hubei province lent its name to a deadly flu virus

(4, 5).clue: The examination of the Russian tale "Dead Souls" & other works by the same author

(5, 5).clue: Before this battle, Lord Nelson sent the message to his sailors that "England expects that every man will do his duty"

(0, 0).clue: Appropriately, this villainous movie character's name comes from the Dutch word for "father"
